description: Compare dialectal English plud (“puddle”), from Middle English pludde (“small pool, puddle”).

verbs.description: plodge (third-person singular simple present plodges, present participle plodging or plodgin, simple past and past participle plodged)

entries.meaning: (Tyneside) and (Wearside) To wade or splash around especially in the sea, or in puddles or mud.

examples: The college system protects you, but it is very unfair to say that people at Oxbridge are not living in the real world. They do have some odd slang. ‘I'll p-hole you in the plodge’ meaning ‘I will leave a note for you in the porter’s lodge’ is just one example.
